title: 1 reason why each MLB team will not win the World Series this season

text:
Mar 1, 2017 at 7:31a ET 0Shares 
Hope allegedly springs eternal at this time of year, even for teams that finished hopelessly out of the wild-card race last season. Well, we’re here to throw some shade on your spring sunshine (cue the Debby Downer sad trombone). 
No MLB team is without its faults, not even the defending World Series champions, who won 103 games last regular season and finished 17.5 games ahead in their division. A case can be made for all 30 teams falling short of the ultimate goal this season. (And because injuries are both unpredictable and an easy way out, we aren’t using that as an excuse for any team.) 
So here’s the bad news for every team: USA TODAY Sports Rick Scuteri Angels 
The improved lineup will be betrayed by the not-improved rotation. USA TODAY Sports Rick Scuteri Astros 
The hitting won’t be able to compensate for the disappointing pitching. USA TODAY Sports Jasen Vinlove Athletics 
Their next wave of talented young starting pitchers isn’t polished enough. USA TODAY Sports Kenny Karst Blue Jays 
The opposition will pitch around Josh Donaldson, and no one will make them pay. USA TODAY Sports Dan Hamilton Braves 
The veteran rotation additions actually will set back the rebuild. USA TODAY Sports Reinhold Matay Brewers 
They’re in the wrong Central division to simultaneously rebuild and contend. USA TODAY Sports Rick Scuteri Cardinals 
Even with Dexter Fowler, the reliance on the long ball and lack of athleticism is glaring. USA TODAY Sports Steve Mitchell Cubs 
The aging rotation – minus Jason Hammel – shows the wear and tear of all those innings in 2016. USA TODAY Sports Rick Scuteri Diamondbacks 
The bullpen is where plenty of leads will go to die. USA TODAY Sports Mark J. Rebilas Dodgers 
The bridge to Kenley Jansen proves to be far from stable. USA TODAY Sports Mark J. Rebilas Giants 
In addition to being an odd-numbered year, the middle relief again springs some costly leaks. USA TODAY Sports John Hefti Indians 
All those innings take a toll on all those pitchers (see: Astros, 2016). USA TODAY Sports Mark J. Rebilas Mariners 
Even after all those trades, they still need another starter and a right fielder. USA TODAY Sports Jennifer Buchanan Marlins 
Edinson Volquez, Dan Straily and Jeff Locke aren’t the answers. USA TODAY Sports Steve Mitchell Mets 
Turns out that all those starting pitchers aren’t simultaneously Tom Seaver – even when healthy. USA TODAY Sports Jasen Vinlove Nationals 
The failure to acquire a proven closer is as damaging as many fear. USA TODAY Sports Steve Mitchell Orioles 
"Chris Tillman and the Question Marks" actually becomes an accurate nickname for the rotation. USA TODAY Sports Nick Turchiaro Padres 
There’s a reason no one ever said that “corner infielders win championships” – though that’s where San Diego is strongest (Wil Myers, Yangervis Solarte). USA TODAY Sports Brett Davis Phillies 
Jeremy Hellickson and Clay Buchholz aren’t Cliff Lee and Cole Hamels. USA TODAY Sports Eric Hartline Pirates 
Shuffling three stud outfielders is a luxury, but shuffling countless back-of-the-rotation starters is a shell game. USA TODAY Sports Jonathan Dyer Rangers 
There’s too much of a rotation drop-off after Cole Hamels and Yu Darvish. USA TODAY Sports Jerome Miron Rays 
Even if there are no more trades, the talent level doesn’t match up in the division, let alone the league. USA TODAY Sports Kim Klement Reds 
The rotation and/or bullpen remains likely to surrender the rare lead it’s given. Cincinnati Enquirer via USA TODAY NETWORK Sam Green Red Sox 
The young hitters slump, and there isn’t a productive enough veteran to compensate. USA TODAY Sports Kim Klement Rockies 
Expectations for the young starters are roughly a mile too high. USA TODAY Sports Matt Kartozian Royals 
The bullpen – once the team’s biggest strength – becomes its biggest weakness. USA TODAY Sports John Rieger Tigers 
There won’t be enough rainouts/off days to allow Justin Verlander and Michael Fulmer to combine for 80 starts. USA TODAY Sports Reinhold Matay Twins 
Even the Cubs endured a frustrating rebuild; check back in 2020 or so. USA TODAY Sports Patrick Gorski White Sox 
The veteran sell-off – though temporarily on hold – is far from over. USA TODAY Sports Jordan Johnson Yankees 
It’s Masahiro Tanaka and no one else when it comes to reliable starters. USA TODAY Sports Butch Dill
